title: Christian Gonzalez on Patriots extension talks: ‘I don’t want to be anywhere else’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Christian Gonzalez is open to signing a contract extension with the New England Patriots this offseason.
Gonzalez, under contract through 2026, delivered a standout postseason performance, enhancing his prospects for a lucrative deal.
Patriots can exercise a fifth-year option on Gonzalez's rookie contract, potentially delaying free agency until 2028.

title: Man dies after being struck by MBTA commuter rail train in Haverhill
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: An adult man died after being struck by an MBTA commuter rail train in Haverhill early Tuesday morning.
The Haverhill Line experienced widespread service disruptions due to the incident, with several trains delayed or canceled.
MBTA Transit Police and Essex County District Attorney's Office are investigating the circumstances surrounding the man's death.

title: Boston Raising Cane’s faces eviction over chicken finger odor, lawsuit says
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Raising Cane's in Boston is suing landlord over eviction threat citing chicken finger odor complaints.
The lawsuit claims the landlord wants to lease space to Panda Express, violating Raising Cane's exclusivity deal.
Raising Cane's spent over $200,000 on odor mitigation, citing building issues as cause, not restaurant operations.

title: Revolution reveal ‘Independence Day’ jersey
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution unveiled the 'Independence Day' jersey to celebrate the USA's 250th anniversary with a fireworks-themed design.
The jersey will be worn during the 2026 and 2027 MLS seasons, paired with navy shorts and red, white, and blue socks.
Fans can purchase the jersey at pop-up locations at Boston's Old State House and Ducali Pizzeria & Bar on February 10.

title: About a dozen vehicles damaged by a bridge joint on I-91 in Western Mass.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: About a dozen vehicles were damaged by a protruding bridge joint on I-91 near mile marker 9 in Massachusetts.
MassDOT crews cut the raised joint after being notified, while State Police assisted vehicles in the breakdown lane.
Affected drivers can file claims online, but state law only allows recovery for personal injury, not property damage.

title: North Andover officer shot by colleague argues judge is biased and should be removed
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Officer Kelsey Fitzsimmons files a motion for Judge Kathleen McCarthy-Neyman's recusal, citing bias in her trial.
Fitzsimmons claims McCarthy-Neyman improperly investigated and held her without bail, affecting her case's fairness.
Fitzsimmons's lawyers allege McCarthy-Neyman has economic interest in North Andover's financial liability, impacting impartiality.

title: Eli Lilly snaps up Watertown biotech in $2.4 billion deal
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Eli Lilly acquires Watertown's Orna Therapeutics for $2.4 billion, aiming to enhance its genetic medicine capabilities.
Orna Therapeutics specializes in circular RNA technology to stimulate immune cell production within patients' bodies.
In 2025, acquisitions of Massachusetts biotech firms totaled $20 billion, a decrease from $42.51 billion in 2024.

title: Boston man paroled after serving 16 years of life sentence for fatal stabbing outside bar
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Corey Patterson, convicted of a 2009 murder outside an Allston bar, paroled after 16 years in prison.
Parole Board cited Patterson's sobriety, educational achievements, and community support as reasons for granting parole.
Patterson's parole conditions include electronic monitoring, curfew, and participation in mental health counseling.

title: ‘You’re going to feel the pain’: Kurt Warner’s advice to Drake Maye after losing Super Bowl LX
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: The Patriots, with quarterback Drake Maye, lost Super Bowl LX to the Seahawks 29-13 despite a strong 14-win season.
Kurt Warner advised Maye to focus on accomplishments, highlighting the Patriots' progress from back-to-back 4-13 seasons.
Warner emphasized the importance of perspective and leadership, citing Coach Mike Vrabel's influence to prevent setbacks.

title: Making movies, like making sausages, is not pretty. Just ask John Sayles.
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: John Sayles, an Oscar-nominated director, discusses his latest novel 'Crucible' and the challenges of modern filmmaking.
'Crucible' explores Detroit's Prohibition era, labor movements, and Henry Ford's Amazonian city, Fordlandia.
Sayles will have public appearances in Cambridge, Duxbury, and Newburyport from February 10-14, 2026.
